desire

For so I might often times direct my negotiation to

The answearing of
e Placcart, I did thinke in my
last to yo
r
H. to be very requisit, especially be-
ing done by my L. effectually, and in a temperat
kind. For doutles suche Pamphlets prevaile very
muche w
t
this people. I did well hope
at
eir
printed copies would have bin called in, but I see
them nowe in every mans hand: and my L. Apologie
is greatly expected, many suspending their judge-
ments, till
ei heare w
at
he can say. For surely
e wisest of them heere, will hardly conceave so
farre,
at as to thinke,
at if a man of his q
a
litie
were charged so unjustly, he would putt it up
quietly w
t
out any answear. And besides it will
engender a greater gelousie and distrust in this
people against
e Inglishe nation: who are already
growen into as great a disgrace among them, as
ever were
e Frenche. For they are come to that
passe,
at whatsoever is complained of against us,
be it never so absurd or unlikely, they both beleve
it, w
t
out further enquirie, and proceede to consulta-
tion uppon it, w
t
suche heat and passion, as I ne-
ver see them goe to it, w
t
so good a will against
e
Ennemie. It may be feared perhaps,
at
e wri-
ting of Contradictorie bookes, will but exasperat their
humo
rs
e more, and occasion greater disunion:
wherof, for mine owne part, I have no doubt in
e world

tie
unto

Barnevelt
came to visit me, of whose speeches
to make yo
r

But I was rounder w
t

he giveth me great hope, by his protestations, of alte-

ding w

her Ma
tie
. The Deputies for England
departed from hens 3 daies
since:
but I thinke they will
make 3 or 4 daies stay in
Zeland.
The
generall state of these Provinces groweth every day
weaker. For
e drumme goeth in sundrie places,
and hardly a souldier can be gotten. The Ennemie
is before
Blienbeecke
w
t
e Canon: and
Berche
hath
sent hither, to knowe whether they shall abandon the
towne, and salve
e Artillerie: for
at they live up-
pon their magazine, and see no meanes to be revictualed.
Moreover
e Ennemie hath taken a Fort by
He
m
ert
and endevoureth to impale
e 2 rivers of
e
Wael
and
Maese
: w
ch
will be
e losse of half a score tow-
nes together, if he speede of his purpose, and a no-
table hindraunce to
e chiefest traffique of
Dort
and all
e townes adjoining. The
Councel
heere hath resolved to reside at
Utrecht
for a
time, supposing
at their presence wilbe a great
c
o
fort and a strength to
at contrey for many respectes.
Howbeit it is likely my
L. of Buckhursts
co
m
ing
will alter their purpose. As I have
signified in some former letters to yo
r
H. and my
L. Tresuro
r
,
e dissention between
e Governo
r
and
Captens of
Berghen,
and other great abuses among them,
doth give great occasion of offense to this people. And
though thinges doe not stand by many degrees in so
badde termes, as they will needes be persuaded, yet
it is highe time they should be reduced to some better
discipline. In w
ch
respect they have intreated
me earnestly, assoone as possibly I shall be able,
to goe thither, w
t
suche other Commissioners as they
will appoint: w
ch
I hope to doe w
t
in these 5 daies.

I have putte my L. of Buckhurst in minde, of two
principall pointes,
in
w
ch
it wilbe necessary to have
e
decision of some learned Civilians: for
at otherwise,
he shall finde them heere very obstinat and stiffe, in
maintening prejudiciall mater unto us. It may
please yo
r
H. to reade, and if yo
w
thinke good,
to cause

And
so I take my humble leave. From
e Hage
May 11. 89. Yo
r
